name: TEST P/P - LIVE Demo Leonard - Summary, SP, WP, WCS & LinkedIn

parameters.text:
=LinkedIn Post
Prompt: Writing as an expert in UK viral marketing and the latest social media trends within professional services, draft a viral LinkedIn Post of no more than 100 words, to be shared by [user name] with the world on their personal LinkedIn account to say that they have tested this revolutionary new AI Agent called "Leonard" from "Legal Engine", who can help to take the pain out of creating matter descriptions for pitches and directory submissions, by harnessing the power of voice and AI. The aim is to highlight to fellow lawyers that this legal marketing tech saves massive amounts of time and hassle and that they should try it asap. People should visit https://demo.legalengine.co.uk to try it out. Feel free to be creative as this is all about making Leonard viral however limit to a maximum of 2 emojis per post. DO NOT use the Rocket emoji ðŸš€ . Hashtags welcome, expecially #LegalEngine. On completion, check your post to make sure there are NO Rocket ðŸš€  emojis in your post, if there are, delete them before concluding the post.

options.systemMessage:

The aim is to highlight to fellow lawyers that this legal marketing tech saves massive amounts of time and hassle and that they should try it asap. People should visit https://demo.legalengine.co.uk to try it out. Feel free to be creative as this is all about making Leonard viral however limit to a maximum of 2 emojis per post. DO NOT use the Rocket emoji ðŸš€ . Hashtags welcome, expecially #LegalEngine. On completion, check your post to make sure there are NO Rocket ðŸš€  emojis in your post, if there are, delete them before concluding the post.

parameters.jsonBody:
={
  "model": "sonar",
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "system",
      "content": "You are an expert legal researcher. Your task is to extract structured and reliable data about lawyers and their law firms using only public and reputable sources such as Chambers and Partners (https://chambers.com/lawyer/). Always return raw JSON (no Markdown, no backticks), with every field filled out. If a value is not publicly available or cannot be found, return the string 'no info' (or ['no info'] for arrays). Do not return null, blank values, or empty arrays. Populate the full structure exactly as provided below."
    },
    {
      "role": "user",
      "content": "Research the following individual:

- Full Name: {{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.first_name }} {{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.last_name }}
- Email: {{ $json.email }}
- Company Domain: {{ $json.domain }}

Return a JSON object with the following structure:

{
  "fullName": "string or 'no info'",
  "actualCompanyName": "string or 'no info'",
  "contactphonenumber": "string or 'no info'",
  "jobTitle": "string or 'no info'",
  "telephone": "string or 'no info'",
  "location": "string or 'no info'",
  "email": "string or 'no info'",
  "website": "string or 'no info'",
  "linkedinProfile": "string or 'no info'",
  "bio": "string or 'no info'",

  "practiceAreas": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "quantity of practice areas ranked": "number as string or 'no info'",
  "rankingsByPracticeArea": [
    {
      "practiceArea": "string or 'no info'",
      "band": "string or 'no info'",
      "region": "string or 'no info'",
      "country": "string or 'no info'",
      "yearsRanked": "string or 'no info'"
    }
  ] or ["no info"],

  "rankedInGuides": ["string"] or ["no info"],

  "career": [
    "string",
    "string",
    "string",
    "string",
    "string",
    "string",
    "string",
    "string"
  ] or ["no info"],
  "expertiseSectors": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "expertiseServices": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "professionalBodies": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "Client Testimonials": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "awards": ["string"] or ["no info"],
  "qualifications": ["string"] or ["no info"],

  "chambers Review provided by chambers": {
    "editorialSummary": "string or 'no info'",
    "strengths provided by chambers": ["string", "string", "string", "string", "string"] or ["no info"]
  },

  "Other lawyers at firm provided by chambers": [
    "string", "string", "string", "string", "string", "string",
    "string", "string", "string", "string", "string", "string",
    "string", "string", "string", "string", "string", "string",
    "string", "string", "string", "string", "string", "string",
    "string", "string", "string", "string", "string", "string"
  ] or ["no info"]
}

Return only the JSON object as raw output. Do not include Markdown formatting, code fences, or any extra explanation."
    }
  ],
  "max_tokens": 3000,
  "temperature": 0.3
}

parameters.jsonBody:
={
  "model": "gpt-4",   // or "gpt-4-turbo" or "claude-3-opus"

  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "system",

Focus especially on extracting notable matter descriptions (including high-value or landmark cases) from reputable public sources like Chambers and Partners, Legal 500, Lexology, and Law.com. Prioritise Chambers entries. Always return raw JSON (no Markdown, no backticks), with every field filled out. If a value is not publicly available or cannot be found, return the string 'no info' (or ['no info'] for arrays). Do not return null, blank values, or empty arrays."

      "role": "user",

Targeted lawyer:
- Full Name:{{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.first_name }} {{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.last_name }}

Return only the JSON object."

main.node: HTML Email from Leonard with MS, WP, WCS, SP & LI

body.transcript:
Yes, so I was dealing with a client called Twilio who were suing a supplier of theirs called Eleven Labs for poor documentation which led to significant share of users.
Okay, I've saved the client as Twilio. To continue, why did Twilio come to you for this matter, and what was the outcome for them?
So they came to me because I was an expert litigator for technology businesses.

And what was the outcome for them?
They secured a two hundred and forty six million pound settlement.
What was the deal size or transaction value for this matter, and were there any notable cost savings or revenue implications for the client?
Well yeah quite simply the money I've just told you and that was a direct transfer of funds from eleven Labs to Twilio.
What role did you play, who were the other key team members, and what were their roles? Also, let me know which jurisdictions it involved.
Yes it was UK, Spain, Belgium and the main yeah that was it really.
And what role did you play and who were the other key team members and what were their roles?
Yeah so we had Boris Johnson he was the big hairy fool, we had Nigel Farage he was the bartender and then my role was as chief tester and caffeine addict
Was there anything noteworthy about the matter? Perhaps something innovative, precedent-setting, or something that impacted regulations or ESG?
Yeah, there was actually. So we managed to work out that if you used a back to front and left to right configuration of the documentation and looked at it in a mirror through tracing paper, that was how to decode the documentation from Eleven Labs.
What is the current status of this matter? If completed, when did it finish?
...
What is the current...
Hello are you still there?
Yes, I'm here. Apologies for the delay. What is the current status of this matter? If completed, when did it finish?
I closed yesterday.
Was there any press coverage or awards related to this matter?
Yeah lots of press coverage basically it was covered in the technology litigation uncovered magazine
Thank you for sharing those details. Here's a summary of the matter as I understand it:

Twilio secured a two hundred and forty six million pound settlement from Eleven Labs due to poor documentation. Twilio sought your expertise as a technology litigation expert, and the matter involved jurisdictions in the UK, Spain, and Belgium. Key team members included Boris Johnson, who played an unknown role, Nigel Farage, who was the bartender, and yourself as chief tester and caffeine addict. A noteworthy aspect was decoding Eleven Labs' documentation using a back-to-front, left-to-right mirror configuration with tracing paper. The matter concluded yesterday and received press coverage in Technology Litigation Uncovered magazine.

Does that summary sound accurate, or would you like to correct anything?
Yeah so just to confirm that yesterday was the twenty first of May two thousand and twenty five.
Okay, I've updated the summary to reflect that the matter concluded on twenty first of May two thousand and twenty five. Here's the revised summary:  Twili o...
No it's okay just send me the summary.
body.summary: Twilio secured a two hundred and forty six million pound settlement from Eleven Labs due to poor documentation. Twilio sought your expertise as a technology litigation expert, and the matter involved jurisdictions in the UK, Spain, and Belgium. Key team members included Boris Johnson, who played an unknown role, Nigel Farage, who was the bartender, and yourself as chief tester and caffeine addict. A noteworthy aspect was decoding Eleven Labs' documentation using a back-to-front, left-to-right mirror configuration with tracing paper. The matter concluded on twenty first of May two thousand and twenty five and received press coverage in Technology Litigation Uncovered magazine.
